newsitem.title: NICARAGUA: Nicaraguan baby, stuck to mother's intestine, born.
newsitem.headline: Nicaraguan baby, stuck to mother's intestine, born.

text.p: Nicaraguan doctors said on Friday they had successfully delivered an infant last week in an extremely rare case where the placenta had attached itself to the 15-year-old mother's small intestine.

"It is an extremely rare case," Quiroz said. "In the world, the percentage of survival for these babies is between 0.1 and 0.3 percent," gynecologist Sergio Quiroz, assistant director of the Bertha Calderon Hospital, told Reuters.
"The placenta was adhered to the small intestine, which it perforated in order to absorb nutrients," he added.
The little girl, who has not been named, was born surgically to 15-year-old Silvia Jimenez who was reported in good condition and recovering from the birth.
"The mother is totally recovered and the pediatricians have given the baby a good prognosis," Quiroz said.
The baby weighed about four pounds (1.8 kg) at birth and is still in intensive care.

The young mother arrived at the hospital two weeks ago when a check showed it was an abnormal pregnancy. Doctors decided to operate three weeks short of the due date. Most such babies are aborted when discovered on time.
